heading: did sun inflate mitnick damages?
subheading: sun microsystems said that kevin mitnick's theft of source code cost the company us$80 million. there's just one problem, says the cracker's attorney: sun gives the code away. by lindsey arent.
author: lindsey arent
text: the attorney for celebrity cracker kevin mitnick said friday that sun microsystems has in effect overestimated by us$80 million the damages his client has caused the company. in company documents published earlier this month by the hacking journal 2600, sun claimed that mitnick stole the source code for its solaris operating system, a theft which reportedly cost the company us$80 million.but sun recently began giving away the solaris source code to preapproved educational institutions, and it plans to sell the code to other qualified developers for $100.donald randolph, mitnick's attorney, said sun's estimate just doesn't add up."apparently it's now being offered for free," said randolph. "we sincerely hope that the court will take this information under consideration in determining whether kevin mitnick must reimburse sun microsystems for his activities."sun declined to comment on the case, but 2600 magazine said that the $80 million claim against mitnick matches the price the company paid to purchase the unix-based operating system from at&t in 1994.jennifer granick, a bay area attorney who defends clients accused of computer-related crimes, said that sun is on shaky ground with its claim."what that says is that sun's need to keep this information secret is not as essential as the case made it out to be," said granick, who has worked with convicted cracker kevin poulsen.
